subject: Re: JUnit add-on for historical/statistical/trend analysis?
msgSnippet: ... Kirk, DevCreek can show a detailed review of the past day s testing and also historical charts with trending information. The complete history of test run
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "David Saff" <saff@...> wrote:
> Is DevCreek anything like what you're looking for?
>
> On 8/27/07, kirkandsheila <kirk@...> wrote:
> > Hi all,
> >
> > I'm doing some research to determine what products/projects are out
> > there to perform historical/statistical/trend analysis on JUnit
> > results. Ideally, I'd like to be able to break down the JUnit results
> > that can be filtered, aggregated, and so forth for reports.

Kirk, DevCreek can show a detailed review of the past day's testing
and also historical charts with trending information. The complete
history of test run and test method executions are recorded for each
developer on the team. Every test run inside of the developer's IDE is
recorded rather than just those triggered by the build process after
check-in. We have an Eclipse Java plug-in ready for use with JUnit,
and a web API to collect JUnit or other metrics from outside of
Eclipse. We would be happy to work with you if you are using JUnit
from an alternative IDE or text editor. If you are happy sharing your
data with the community then the service is free to use.

http://devcreek.com

You can get detailed feedback on your recent testing either in Eclipse
or on the website. We present each executed test run, whether it was
successful or not and the number of tests involved. This can help you
to become more aware of how you are testing, alert you when you are
straying from your preferred behaviour (for example when you are lost
in the debugger for hours on end rather than writing a new test), or
act as a measure for adopting a new testing style. We also show some
simple heuristics and a list of added test methods. The intention is
that this data can feed back into your own and your team's learning
practices.

I haven't done much coding the last few days, but feel free to get an
idea of the recorded activity by looking at the DevCreek project
itself (TestCreek is an earlier project name for DevCreek):

Project activity: https://devcreek.com/project/TestCreek

My own testing activity:
https://devcreek.com/principalActivity/TestCreek/DGJ

The other side is historical charts. We keep a history of the test
executions for the entire duration of the project. We have number of
built-in reports that

cover a range of testing analyses. For example total test methods,
frequency of test run

executions, test durations, results and so on. We also have some
reports that get closer to

quality and process measures such as time taken to fix broken tests,
the cost for adding a

new test method (by number of executed tests/new test method), testing
by hour-of-day or

day-of-week and so on.

Currently there isn't much control over filtering and manipulating
these charts though we intend to move to a more interactive mechanism.
You can download your project's data as XML for custom analysis. You
can also explore any of the open projects to learn how they are
testing. We have collected about 25 person years of testing activity
so far. This sort of

data is so new, we are all still exploring the
space to find the gems, so getting as many people involved as possible
is very useful.

Here are the reports collected so far during the development of
DevCreek itself:

https://devcreek.com/reports/projects/TestCreek/index.html

All of the open projects, such as DevCreek/TestCreek, are open to the
public for us all to learn from. Feel free to click around.

We have also put together a short animation of the first nine months
of testing while developing DevCreek. It's not a report but does
attempt to provide an alternative kind of view onto the development
process.

https://community.devcreek.com/space/David+Jones/blog/2007-09-10_1


If you have any questions about JUnit integration, or alternative
reports please ask.

Cheers
David Jones
